author: By Florence Fabricant

content: The chef and cookbook author Vikas Khanna, whose New York debut many years ago was at the Michelin-starred Junoon, now has a place to call his own here. He and his business partner, Jimmy Rizvi, who owns GupShup and other restaurants, settled on the East Village. “The space is so unassuming but unforgettable when you walk in,” Mr. Khanna said. He could not resist the flight of steps going down from the street level, which reminded him of the entrance to the famous Golden Temple in Amritsar in his native Punjab in the north of India. “It makes the entrance surprisingly majestic,” he said. Then why call it Bungalow? In the India of the Raj, bungalows were aristocratic dwellings. First there is a bar area with tables, then a semi-open kitchen and beyond that a spacious dining room, the rear portion of which has greenery and a skylight. The menu trawls Indian cooking from Kashmir south to Kerala, with dahi puri stuffed with lentils from Varanasi, a Kashmiri dish made with lotus roots, a tart Jewish-Indian chicken curry Chitranee, malai chicken with cheese, Muslim saffron bread called sheermal, Rajasthani pulled lamb, and spicy shrimp balchão, which has Portuguese roots. Classics like chicken biryani are also on the menu. Mr. Khanna, who lives in New York, plans to spend most of his time on the premises. “It’s my dream,” he said.

content: This hen’s name is Nina (above, center). I was visiting a friend this past November in the Canary Islands — a place made for hiking and forgetting about fashion — and the hen befriended me. Wherever I went, she came to sit on my lap. My mother passed away in September; another reason I needed to urgently disconnect. Years ago, she put together a cute baby album (above, right). My parents, who divorced when I was very young, used to call me Apple — I was strawberry blond and had massive red cheeks. My older brother, Philippe, and I were raised in Belgium partly by my conservative, but always supportive, maternal grandparents. For Y/Project’s spring 2017 campaign (above, left) [Martens, 40, has been the French brand’s creative director since 2013], we decided to shoot in Bruges with only my family and childhood friends as models. I never expected my grandfather André Arnalsteen — someone who volunteered to fight in World War II when he was 18 — to say, “Of course, with pleasure.” My grandfather on my dad’s side, Michel Martens, was a mirror artist. He died a long time ago, but I have this piece by him (below, right) in my Paris apartment. In the ’90s, my grandparents took me to a retrospective of [the 15th-century Flemish painter] Hans Memling (below, center right). I remember being completely blown away by the colors on the canvas; the detail you find in every single square centimeter is ridiculous. You can see the hairs of the velvets.

title: Man Charged With Murder in Death of 3-Year-Old Boy in Brooklyn
description: Denim Brown was pronounced dead after being found face down and unconscious in a bathtub at an East Flatbush apartment, the police said.
content: A 29-year-old man has been charged with killing a 3-year-old Brooklyn boy who was found with head injuries in a bathtub at the building where the child’s mother had left him in a neighbor’s care, the police said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Meets Amid Worries That Inflation Progress Might Stall
description: Inflation had been moderating steadily, but it is now hovering around 3 percent. Will lowering it fully to normal levels prove difficult?
content: Slowing America’s rapid inflation has been an unexpectedly painless process so far. High interest rates are making it expensive to take out a mortgage or borrow to start a business, but they have not slammed the brakes on economic growth or drastically pushed up unemployment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Paulin Hountondji, Revolutionary African Philosopher, Dies at 81
description: He rebelled against efforts to force African ways of thinking into the European worldview. His thoughts had the effect of a bomb in African intellectual life.
content: Paulin Hountondji, a philosopher from Benin whose critique of colonial-era anthropology helped transform African intellectual life, died on Feb. 2 at his home in Cotonou, Benin’s largest city. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Evergrande Founder Accused of Exaggerating Revenue by $78 Billion
description: China’s securities regulator fined the developer’s founder, Hui Ka Yan, and banned him from participating in the country’s financial markets for life.
content: China Evergrande Group exaggerated its revenue by more than $78 billion and committed securities fraud over two years before its spectacular collapse in 2021, a top Chinese regulator said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and David C. Adams
title: Peter Navarro Begins 4-Month Prison Sentence for Contempt of Congress
description: The former White House trade adviser is the first senior Trump aide to serve time over efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
content: Peter Navarro, a trade adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, reported to federal prison in Miami on Tuesday, becoming the first senior Trump administration official to serve time over his role in the effort to subvert the results of the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and David Pierson
title: Hong Kong Adopts Sweeping Security Laws, Bowing to Beijing
description: The legislation targets “external interference” and the theft of state secrets, with implications for businesses, journalists, civil servants and others.
content: Hong Kong on Tuesday passed national security laws at the behest of Beijing, thwarting decades of public resistance in a move that critics say will strike a lasting blow to the partial autonomy the city had been promised by China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Investors Shrug Off Nvidia’s ‘A.I. Woodstock’
description: The chipmaker unveiled a new high-speed processor at its developer conference to power an “industrial revolution,” but its sky-high valuation is coming under scrutiny.
content: Nvidia’s stock has soared more than fivefold since ChatGPT debuted in November 2022, a rally that has vaulted the chipmaker into the trillion-dollar market cap club on the back of investor fervor for artificial intelligence — and the high-end processors that power these models.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Your Questions About Sodium, Answered
description: How much salt is too much? Should I cut back? We asked experts these and other questions about sodium.
content: Without sodium, you wouldn’t be able to survive. Nerves would fail to fire; muscles wouldn’t contract. But experts say that most people consume far too much of it, increasing their risk of high blood pressure and heart disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules for Immigrant in Case on Deportation Hardship Waiver
description: By a 6-to-3 vote, the court said that federal appeals courts may review many rulings from immigration judges despite a law that sought to limit their jurisdiction.
content: The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that federal appeals courts may review many determinations by immigration judges about whether deporting someone would, in the words of a federal statute, result in “exceptional and extremely unusual hardship” to a relative who is lawfully in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Lawsuit Over New York City’s Property Tax System Can Proceed, Court Says
description: The lawsuit seeks to overturn a system that has been under fire because it favors wealthier homeowners. The housing groups that sued hope to distribute the tax burden more equitably.
content: A lawsuit that could upend New York City’s property tax system was cleared to move forward by the state’s highest court on Tuesday. The decision is a victory for housing groups that complain that the system favors owners of wealthy Brooklyn brownstones and high-end Manhattan condos over renters and owners in lower-income neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Hair That Puts Your Best Face Forward
description: Wet waves, curly mullets and all sorts of braids commanded attention without camouflaging other features.
content: At the recent fashion weeks in New York, London, Milan and Paris, the many wet waves, curly mullets and braids of all sizes in the crowds seemed to be styled with a shared philosophy: Keep it tight at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Unilever to Cut 7,500 Jobs and Spin Off Ben & Jerry’s Ice Cream Unit
description: The consumer goods giant said the moves would make for a “simpler, more focused company” as consumers trade down to cheaper brands amid high inflation.
content: Unilever, the consumer goods giant, said on Tuesday that it would cut 7,500 jobs and spin off its ice cream unit, which includes Ben & Jerry’s, to reduce costs and simplify its portfolio of brands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: The latest tracks from Mdou Moctar, St. Vincent, Willie Nelson and more.
content: First of all, I want to thank Jon Caramanica for filling in for me on Friday. I’ve been doing some traveling, and a bit of record shopping — which means I just might have a record-haul playlist to share with you soon. Stay tuned!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Justices Won’t Block Texas’s Immigration Law, for Now
description: Also, Hong Kong adopted sweeping laws targeting criticism. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The Supreme Court today issued an order that temporarily allows a new Texas law to go into effect, giving state officials the authority to arrest and deport migrants who enter Texas without authorization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Mount Sinai and UnitedHealthcare Reach Insurance Deal
description: The end of the dispute means that Mount Sinai patients with UnitedHealthcare won’t need to find new doctors.
content: After months of stalled contract negotiations, Mount Sinai Health System, a leading New York City hospital system, and the health insurance giant UnitedHealthcare announced a deal on Tuesday that will keep Mount Sinai’s hospitals and doctors in network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian and Terry Parris Jr
title: How Teens Approach the U.S. Election
description: No offense, but if you’re reading this, chances are you’re not a teenager
content: How old are you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Comita
title: An Illustrated Guide to Spring’s New Books
description: Exclusively for T, Marcus Jahmal envisions what happens on page 76 of novels by Neel Mukherjee, Valerie Martin and others.
content: “Food and sake were set out for them on low tables, and farther inside the room was a scarlet futon. … Having been instructed to say nothing, she kept her lips tightly closed as she poured Takahata a drink.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: From Russia, Elaborate Tales of Fake Journalists
description: As the Ukraine war grinds on, the Kremlin has created increasingly complex fabrications online to discredit Ukraine’s leader and undercut aid. Some have a Hollywood-style plot twist.
content: A young man calling himself Mohamed al-Alawi appeared in a YouTube video in August. He described himself as an investigative journalist in Egypt with a big scoop: The mother-in-law of Ukraine’s president had purchased a villa near Angelina Jolie’s in El Gouna, a resort town on the Red Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Block, for Now, Aggressive Texas Immigration Law
description: The law, which empowers local officials to arrest and deport migrants who enter the country without authorization, was challenged by the Biden administration as an affront to federal power.
content: The Supreme Court temporarily sided with Texas on Tuesday in its increasingly bitter fight with the Biden administration over immigration policy, allowing an expansive state law to go into effect that makes it a crime for migrants to enter Texas without authorization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: The Mad Perfumer of Parma
description: Hilde Soliani makes feral scents that evoke everything from oysters to opera houses.
content: The median level of grooming in Parma, Italy, is high. Perhaps among the highest in the world. Supporting this conjecture is the fact that the minimalist Airbnb where I recently stayed for six nights offered not one but two lint-rollers, a blow dryer with countless attachments, a clothing steamer and an iron — but I could find only one roll of toilet paper. From such minor details it is tempting to draw conclusions about what a Parmesan considers a necessity versus what he considers merely an amenity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Martin Luther King Jr. Biographer Wins American History Prize
description: The New-York Historical Society honor goes to Jonathan Eig, whose “King: A Life” presents the civil rights leader as a brilliant, flawed 20th-century “founding father.”
content: Jonathan Eig, the author of “King: A Life,” has been named the winner of the New-York Historical Society’s 2024 Barbara and David Zalaznick Book Prize, which is awarded annually for the best work of American history or biography.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeğinsu
title: Jail Cells? Morgues? Your Cruise Ship Has Some Surprises for You.
description: Here are five unexpected features on ships, some of which you hopefully won’t discover on your own.
content: Cruise ships have hidden features that many passengers, particularly first-timers, don’t know about. Some ships are as big as small cities, and while it’s relatively easy to familiarize yourself with a seemingly endless number of amenities — water parks, tattoo parlors, multiple restaurants — there is also an entire ecosystem, often below passenger decks, that is shrouded in mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tope Folarin
title: Henry Louis Gates Jr. Unpacks Black Literature’s ‘Black Box’
description: In his latest book, the Harvard scholar shows how African American writers have used the written word to shape their reality despite constraints imposed on them from outside.
content: By way of explaining the metaphor that serves as the title of his latest book, “The Black Box,” the Harvard scholar Henry Louis Gates Jr. transcribes a conversation he had with his son-in-law after the birth of his granddaughter 10 years ago:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Brazil Police Recommend Criminal Charges Against Bolsonaro
description: The federal police accused the former president of falsifying his Covid-19 vaccination records.
content: Brazil’s federal police recommended that former President Jair Bolsonaro be criminally charged in a scheme to falsify his Covid-19 vaccine card, partly to travel to the United States during the pandemic, in the latest sign of criminal investigations closing in on the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Alyce McFadden
title: A Special Election in California Will Fill the Seat Vacated by Kevin McCarthy
description: The front-runners are Vince Fong and Mike Boudreaux, the same Republicans who have already secured a spot on the November ballot to fill the seat permanently.
content: Voters in the California district once represented by Kevin McCarthy, the ousted speaker of the House, will head back to the polls Tuesday to choose his interim replacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Apple Keeps Losing Patent Cases. Its Solution: Rewrite the Rules.
description: After losing two complaints before the U.S. International Trade Commission, Apple has stepped up its lobbying to change the agency’s practices.
content: Over the past decade, some of Apple’s biggest regulatory headaches have come from a little-known federal agency called the U.S. International Trade Commission. The agency’s patent judges have found Apple guilty of appropriating innovations in smartphones, semiconductors and smartwatches. And recently, they forced Apple to remove a health feature from Apple Watches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Another Ousted Trump Official, Corey Lewandowski, May Get Convention Role
description: Mr. Lewandowski and Paul Manafort are both being considered for involvement in the Republican National Convention in July.
content: Aides to former President Donald J. Trump are discussing getting Corey Lewandowski, Mr. Trump’s former campaign manager who was shoved out of a pro-Trump super PAC in 2021, involved in the Republican National Convention, according to two people briefed on the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Thielman
title: In These Graphic Novels, Something Is Horribly Amiss
description: Circus tigers, giant spiders, shifting borders and motherhood all threaten to end life as we know it in comics this month.
content: You never know what’s going to go wrong, until you do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Tiffany May
title: In Hong Kong, China’s Grip Can Feel Like ‘Death by a Thousand Cuts’
description: As Hong Kong’s leaders embrace China’s top-down political culture, many believe the city’s dynamism and vitality are slipping away.
content: Once one of Asia’s most high-flying cities, Hong Kong is now grappling with a deep pessimism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: The Timeless Appeal of Champagne and Fried Chicken
description: Some of the greatest combinations pair exalted wines with foods considered humble. Exploring beyond the conventional can be joyous.
content: Which came first, the fried chicken or the Champagne?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: R.B.G. Award Organizer Cancels Ceremony After Fallout Over Honorees
description: The Opperman Foundation said it would “reconsider its mission” but did not say whether those selected, including Elon Musk and Rupert Murdoch, would still receive the award.
content: The organizer behind an honor named for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a lifelong champion of women’s rights and liberal causes, is canceling the award ceremony scheduled for April after facing blistering criticism from her family and friends over several of this year’s planned recipients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Ramy Youssef: Making Sense of the World and Finding Faith (With Jokes)
description: The very busy comic has a special and an “S.N.L.” hosting gig on the books. He and his friends kid each other, “We make TV like immigrants. We’re always working.”
content: In the week after he appeared as a presenter at the Oscars, the comic Ramy Youssef, a creator and director of the Hulu series “Ramy” and Emma Stone’s co-star in “Poor Things,” was taking meetings in Hollywood on what’s known as a water-bottle tour — “except without the water bottle,” he said. He is fasting for Ramadan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Californians Share Their Pandemic Silver Linings, Four Years Later
description: Readers have been writing to me about ways that, despite all the tragedy, Covid brought something unexpectedly positive into their lives.
content: It was four years ago today that Gov. Gavin Newsom ordered all Californians to stay home to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus. For many people, the drastic move was the moment when the pandemic became truly, horribly real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Torday
title: A Jewish Family Contends With History’s Ghosts
description: Toby Lloyd centers religion and politics in his novel, “Fervor,” but with a light, mystical touch.
content: In one of the most perceptive of her late essays, “God’s Language,” Toni Morrison sets out her objective as a novelist: “to construct a work in which religious belief is central to the narrative itself.” How, she asks, can the writer use the language religion has handed us in a way that the 21st-century reader can hear? Not an easy task — but one that Toby Lloyd, in his magnificent, indelible debut novel, “Fervor,” takes on with confidence, and with resounding success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Jessica Testa
title: Dries Van Noten Announces Retirement
description: The Belgian designer, known for his glorious use of color and prints, remained independent for years. Now he’s going out on his own terms.
content: In a shock to the fashion world, Dries Van Noten announced that he was stepping down as creative director of the brand that bears his name. His fall 2024 men’s show, scheduled to take place in Paris in June, will be his last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
title: Chicago-Area Races Test Progressive Strength
description: A proposed tax change to fund homelessness programs in Chicago and the Democratic primary for Cook County’s chief prosecutor pit moderates against progressives.
content: Two local races in the Chicago area on Tuesday will gauge voters’ enthusiasm for progressive causes in an Illinois primary that lacks drama at the top of the ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Lawmakers Back Motion Meant to Help Bring Peace to Gaza
description: The House of Commons vote endorsing a package of conflict-ending measures came after language calling on Canada to immediately recognize a State of Palestine was removed.
content: The polarized debate in Canada over the conflict in Gaza spilled into the country’s House of Commons on Monday as lawmakers voted to endorse a wide-ranging package of nonbinding measures that a left-leaning opposition party had presented as way to bring peace to the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Currid and Mark Josephson
title: OK, Class, First We Shoot the Deer
description: A Missouri high school program teaches students to take freshly killed animals from the field to the classroom and into the kitchen.
content: At Maysville High School in Maysville, Mo., population 1,100, classes can be a little tough for the squeamish. Course work can involve assigned reading and algebra, but also a serious amount of blood and guts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Gets a Kick Out of Bothering Trump
description: “Donald Trump has said I’m not talented so many times, Eric is starting to get jealous,” Kimmel said after the ex-president bashed him (again) on Fox News.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W.J. Hennigan and Jillian Weinberger
title: The United States Is Living Under a ‘Nuclear Monarchy’
description: Should one person have that much power?
content: In America, it’s the president who decides whether the country goes to nuclear war. In this audio essay, W.J. Hennigan argues against the United States’ sole decision-making authority on nuclear weapons. The country’s nuclear power structure, he says, is “too much power for one person to have, to decide whether or not the world as we know it will exist.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Shogun’ Episode 5 Recap: Communication Breakdown
description: John Blackthorne and Lady Mariko learn the responsibility that comes with freedom when Buntaro returns.
content: Sometimes there’s nothing worse than a miracle. On this week’s episode of “Shogun,” Lady Mariko is shocked when her lord husband, Buntaro, emerges unscathed from what seemed like certain death at the hands of Lord Ishido’s soldiers back in Osaka. Though a brave and formidable warrior, he’s also a emotionally and physically abusive husband. To Buntaro, being forced to share a house with a barbarian like John Blackthorne is like living in the monkey house at a zoo. What he would do if he found out about the clandestine dalliance between Blackthorne and Mariko is all too obvious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Hey, New Yorkers: Are You Trying to Sell Your Home Using a Real Estate Agent? We Want to Hear From You.
description: New changes to the way homes are bought and sold are causing confusion among buyers, sellers and real estate agents. We want to hear your experience of selling a home in New York City in 2024.
content: In the aftermath of the recent legal settlement calling for the National Association of Realtors to amend its rules on how Realtors are compensated for a home sale, many home buyers and sellers across the United States are wondering how the changes will affect them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Gambia and the Campaign Against Cutting
description: Female genital mutilation is still widespread despite international efforts to end it.
content: Yesterday, lawmakers in Gambia voted to advance legislation that would legalize female genital cutting. Local analysts believe it is likely to pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland
title: Saudi Arabia Plans $40 Billion Push Into Artificial Intelligence
description: The Middle Eastern country is creating a gigantic fund to invest in A.I. technology, potentially becoming the largest player in the hot market.
content: The government of Saudi Arabia plans to create a fund of about $40 billion to invest in artificial intelligence, according to three people briefed on the plans — the latest sign of the gold rush toward a technology that has already begun reshaping how people live and work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jennifer Sciubba
description: The March 19, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jennifer Sciubba. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: Gannett and McClatchy Cut Back Relationship With A.P.
description: The Associated Press said the decisions by the two major newspaper chains “would not have a material impact on our overall revenue.”
content: Two major American newspaper chains, Gannett and McClatchy, plan to drastically curtail their business relationships with The Associated Press, which supplies news reports and images to outlets around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: The Unbearable Vagueness of Medical ‘Professionalism’
description: Since its inception, this murky term has straddled the dual role of disciplining and inspiring.
content: When Joel Bervell thought about professionalism as an undergrad, he thought of “Grey’s Anatomy.” Specifically, he thought about how residents on the show were expected to be, although often were not: on time, prepared for their cases and respectful to everyone around them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: One Thing Most Countries Have in Common: Unsafe Air
description: New research found that fewer than 10 percent of countries and territories met World Health Organization guidelines for particulate matter pollution last year.
content: Only 10 countries and territories out of 134 achieved the World Health Organization’s standards for a pervasive form of air pollution last year, according to air quality data compiled by IQAir, a Swiss company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: The Islamophobic Smear Campaign Dividing Democrats
description: Adeel Mangi was a judicial shoo-in for Biden. Will Democrats defend him?
content: On paper, President Biden’s nominee to fill a vacancy on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, Adeel Abdullah Mangi, is an archetypical candidate for a federal judgeship. Mangi has a sterling legal education, which he followed with a distinguished career at a high-profile private firm mixing corporate litigation with important pro bono work. He also has a classic American story: He grew up in a poor country dreaming of a career as a lawyer and immigrated to the United States, where he ascended to the heights of his profession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: White House Says Rafah Invasion ‘Would Be a Mistake’, and Trump Can’t Make Bond
description: Plus, a space pioneer remembered.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Are Super Strict Schools Good for Students?
description: Supporters say they help children succeed. Critics say they are oppressive. What do you think?
content: The following paragraphs describe a secondary school in England:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Addario and Victoria Kim
title: Barren Fields and Empty Stomachs: Afghanistan’s Long, Punishing Drought
description: In a country especially vulnerable to climate change, a drought has displaced entire villages and left millions of children malnourished.
content: They awake in the mornings to find another family has left. Half of one village, the entirety of the next have departed in the years since the water dried up — in search of jobs, of food, of any means of survival. Those who remain pick apart the abandoned homes and burn the bits for firewood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Want to Know What Trump Will Do? Listen to What He Says.
description: You don’t talk about “poisoning the blood of our country” to pass the time.
content: One of the most enduring bits of folk wisdom about American politics is the notion that a promise made on the campaign trail is almost never a promise kept. The only thing you can count on from a politician, and especially a presidential candidate, is that you can’t count on anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Blinken Warns China Against Armed Attack on Philippines
description: The secretary of state struck a balance seemingly meant to deter China while avoiding a dangerous escalation with Beijing.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken warned China on Tuesday that an “armed” attack against Philippine vessels in the South China Sea would trigger a mutual self-defense pact between Washington and Manila, a reflection of rising tensions in the region that risk dragging the United States into armed conflict with Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Illinoise,’ a Sufjan Stevens Dance Musical, Is Moving to Broadway
description: The production will make its transfer unusually fast, with an opening set for April 24, just 29 days after it wraps up a sold-out run at the Park Avenue Armory.
content: “Illinoise,” a dance-driven, dialogue-free musical adapted from a much-loved 2005 album by Sufjan Stevens, will transfer to Broadway next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules for Muslim Man in Challenge to No-Fly List
description: The government had contended that removing Yonas Fikre from the list made moot his lawsuit asserting violations of his constitutional rights.
content: The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Tuesday in favor of a Muslim man who said he had been put on the no-fly list in retaliation for refusing to become a government informant. The court rejected the government’s contention that removing the man from the list had rendered his case moot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Congressional Republicans Block Aid to Haiti Amid Unrest
description: Republicans have refused to release $40 million in security assistance and questioned how it would be used and whether it could fall into the hands of the gangs stoking the upheaval.
content: Congressional Republicans are blocking $40 million in aid that the Biden administration has requested to help stabilize Haiti amid an increase in gang violence there, despite warnings that continued chaos could lead to a humanitarian crisis and drive migrants fleeing the country into the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Spring
description: What are your favorite sights, sounds, tastes and smells of spring?
content: In the Northern Hemisphere, the vernal equinox — when day and night are equal in length — will officially take place Tuesday, March 19, at 11:06 p.m. In simpler terms: Goodbye winter, spring is here!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Alabama Republicans Pass Expansive Legislation Targeting D.E.I.
description: The measure would not only cut funding to diversity programs at public colleges, but also limit the teaching of “divisive concepts” surrounding race and gender.
content: Alabama Republicans pushed through a sprawling measure on Tuesday that would not only ban state funding for diversity, equity and inclusion programs at public universities, local boards of education and government agencies, but also limit the teaching of “divisive concepts” surrounding race, gender and identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Birthrates Are Plummeting Worldwide. Why?
description: The demographer Jennifer D. Sciubba examines why families — even in wealthy nations — are having fewer children.
content: For a long time, the story about the world’s population was that it was growing too quickly. There were going to be too many humans, not enough resources, and that spelled disaster. But now the script has flipped. Fertility rates have declined dramatically, from about five children per woman 60 years ago to just over two today. About two-thirds of us now live in a country or area where fertility rates are below replacement level. And that has set off a new round of alarm, especially in certain quarters on the right and in Silicon Valley, that we’re headed toward demographic catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: DNA From Discarded Gum Leads to Conviction in 1980 Oregon Murder
description: Robert Arthur Plympton was found guilty of murdering Barbara Mae Tucker, 19, who was kidnapped, sexually assaulted and beaten to death on a community college campus near Portland.
content: In the end, it was a discarded piece of chewing gum, casually spit on the ground in 2021, that was the key to solving the cold-case murder of a college student that had confounded the authorities in Oregon for more than four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Cade Metz
title: Microsoft Hires DeepMind Co-Founder to Run Consumer A.I.
description: Mustafa Suleyman is leaving a start-up called Inflection to take the senior position with Microsoft.
content: Mustafa Suleyman, a co-founder of Google’s DeepMind artificial intelligence lab, is leaving the start-up he was running to lead Microsoft’s consumer A.I. business, in another sign of Microsoft’s aggressive plans for the technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Westbrook and Lindsay Crouse
title: It Turns Out the ‘Deep State’ Is Actually Kind of Awesome
description: Meet the unsung heroes making our country great.
content: As America closes in on a major election, mistrust is brewing around the mysterious government entity that’s now denounced in scary-sounding terms — “the deep state” and “the swamp.” What do those words even mean? Who exactly do they describe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Making the Case for Capitalism
description: A new book argues that short-term profit incentives can deliver long-term changes to benefit the climate.
content: Combating the climate crisis is the ultimate long-term challenge. Can society rapidly overhaul energy production, transportation, heavy industry, agriculture and more in order to prevent truly catastrophic global warming?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum

author: By Adina Glickstein
title: I Was Lonely In a New City. This Tech Trick Helped Me Belong
description: There is a comfort in having somewhere tried and true to go, especially when you’re a stranger in a foreign city.
content: A uniquely 20-something cocktail of ambition, stupidity and wanderlust led me to take a job in Berlin fresh out of college. My due diligence consisted of watching several of Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s movies and calling it a day. I had visited the city before, crashing with lovers and loose acquaintances, but my sense of how to build a life there — or in any new place, for that matter — was nonexistent. The practical matters of adjusting to a new city bedeviled me. After work I longed to navigate the city with purpose but had nowhere in particular to go. Interminable weeks at the office gave way to lonely weekends spent not queuing up for clubs but crying on a floor mattress in Charlottenburg, anxiety taking hold at the thought of another aimless walk. A fun decision made in haste, for all its adventurous merit, had left me lost and lonely.
